case_vignette: A 22-year-old female presents with a brown rough spot on the left shin which she noted when shaving her leg. She thinks it may have been there for a few weeks. She denies any pain, pruritus, or spontaneous bleeding from the site. She cannot recall any trauma that may have caused the lesion.  She denies any personal or family history of skin cancer.   Physical exam reveals a thin, firm brown dome shaped papule on the left shin that invaginates upon pinching.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a brown rough spot on my left shin that I noticed a few weeks ago while shaving.
Has the size or color of the spot changed since you first noticed it?
I haven't noticed any change in the size or color of the spot since I first saw it.
Do you have any similar spots elsewhere on your body?
No, I don't have any similar spots elsewhere on my body.
Have you had any previous skin problems or a history of skin cancer in your family?
No, I don't have any previous skin problems or a family history of skin cancer.
Is the spot itchy, painful, or bleeding?
No, the spot is not itchy, painful, or bleeding.
Have you been exposed to sun frequently or used tanning beds?
I cannot recall any specific trauma or exposure that might have caused the lesion.
Final Diagnosis: Actinic Keratosis.
